node.title: Tenary alloy: free energy issues
node.bodyText:
I had this 3 phase alloy which was set up as a binary alloy with two variants of precipitates as shown below:
[Materials]
  # simple toy free energies
  [./f1]
    type = DerivativeParsedMaterial
    f_name = fc_1
    args = 'c1'
    function = '100.0*(c1-0.34)^2'
  [../]
  # Elastic energy of the phase 1
  [./elastic_free_energy_1]
    type = ElasticEnergyMaterial
    base_name = phase1
    f_name = fe_1
    args = ' '
  [../]
  # Total free energy of the phase 1
  [./Total_energy_1]
    type = DerivativeSumMaterial
    f_name = F1
    sum_materials = 'fc_1 fe_1'
    args = 'c1'
  [../]

  [./f2]
    type = DerivativeParsedMaterial
    f_name = fc_2
    args = 'c2'
    function = '100.0*(c2-0.3111)^2'
  [../]
  # Elastic energy of the phase 2
  [./elastic_free_energy_2]
    type = ElasticEnergyMaterial
    base_name = phase2
    f_name = fe_2
    args = ' '
  [../]
  # Total free energy of the phase 2
  [./Total_energy_2]
    type = DerivativeSumMaterial
    f_name = F2
    sum_materials = 'fc_2 fe_2'
    args = 'c2'
  [../]

  [./f3]
    type = DerivativeParsedMaterial
    f_name = fc_3
    args = 'c3'
    function = '5.0*(c3-0.20)^2'
  [../]
  # Elastic energy of the phase 3
  [./elastic_free_energy_3]
    type = ElasticEnergyMaterial
    base_name = phase3
    f_name = fe_3
    args = ' '
  [../]
  # Total free energy of the phase 3
  [./Total_energy_3]
    type = DerivativeSumMaterial
    f_name = F3
    sum_materials = 'fc_3 fe_3'
    args = 'c3'
  [../]

  # Switching functions for each phase
  # h1(eta1, eta2, eta3)
  [./h1]
    type = SwitchingFunctionMultiPhaseMaterial
    phase_etas = eta1
    all_etas = 'eta1 eta2 eta3'
    h_name = h1
  [../]
  # h2(eta1, eta2, eta3)
  [./h2]
    type = SwitchingFunctionMultiPhaseMaterial
    phase_etas = eta2
    all_etas = 'eta1 eta2 eta3'
    h_name = h2
  [../]
  # h3(eta1, eta2, eta3)
  [./h3]
    type = SwitchingFunctionMultiPhaseMaterial
    phase_etas = eta3
    all_etas = 'eta1 eta2 eta3'
    h_name = h3
  [../]

  # Coefficients for diffusion equation
  [./Dh1]
    type = DerivativeParsedMaterial
    material_property_names = 'D h1'
    function = D*h1
    f_name = Dh1
  [../]
  [./Dh2]
    type = DerivativeParsedMaterial
    material_property_names = 'D h2'
    function = D*h2
    f_name = Dh2
  [../]
  [./Dh3]
    type = DerivativeParsedMaterial
    material_property_names = 'D h3'
    function = D*h3
    f_name = Dh3
  [../]

  # Barrier functions for each phase
  [./g1]
    type = BarrierFunctionMaterial_abs
    g_order = SIMPLE
    eta = eta1
    function_name = g1
  [../]
  [./g2]
    type = BarrierFunctionMaterial_abs
    g_order = SIMPLE
    eta = eta2
    function_name = g2
  [../]
  [./g3]
    type = BarrierFunctionMaterial
    g_order = SIMPLE
    eta = eta3
    function_name = g3
  [../]

  # constant properties
  [./constants]
    type = GenericConstantMaterial
    prop_names  = 'L    kappa  D  misfit  W'
    prop_values = '0.3  0.01   1  0.005  0.01'
  [../]

  #Mechanical properties
  [./Stiffness_phase1]
    type = ComputeElasticityTensor
    C_ijkl = '1982 534 496 1606 605 1788 985 1056 388'    
    base_name = phase1
    fill_method = symmetric9
  [../]
  [./Stiffness_phase2]
    type = ComputeElasticityTensor
    C_ijkl = '1606 534 605 1982 496 1788 1056 985 388'
    base_name = phase2
    fill_method = symmetric9
  [../]
  [./Stiffness_phase3]
    type = ComputeElasticityTensor
    C_ijkl = '2008.5 448.9 918.5 2008.5 918.5 1538.7 779.8 779.8 309.9'    
    base_name = phase3
    fill_method = symmetric9
  [../]

  [./stress_phase1]
    type = ComputeLinearElasticStress
    base_name = phase1
  [../]
  [./stress_phase2]
    type = ComputeLinearElasticStress
    base_name = phase2
  [../]
  [./stress_phase3]
    type = ComputeLinearElasticStress
    base_name = phase3
  [../]

  [./strain_phase1]
    type = ComputeSmallStrain
    displacements = 'disp_x disp_y'
    base_name = phase1
    eigenstrain_names = eigenstrain1
  [../]
  [./strain_phase2]
    type = ComputeSmallStrain
    displacements = 'disp_x disp_y'
    base_name = phase2
    eigenstrain_names = eigenstrain2
  [../]
  [./strain_phase3]
    type = ComputeSmallStrain
    displacements = 'disp_x disp_y'
    base_name = phase3
  [../]

  [./eigen_strain1]
    type = ComputeEigenstrain
    base_name = phase1
    eigen_base = '1 0 0 0 0 0'
    prefactor = misfit
    eigenstrain_name = eigenstrain1
  [../]

  [./eigen_strain2]
    type = ComputeEigenstrain
    base_name = phase2
    eigen_base = '0 1 0 0 0 0'
    prefactor = misfit
    eigenstrain_name = eigenstrain2
  [../]


  # Generate the global stress from the phase stresses
  [./global_stress]
    type = MultiPhaseStressMaterial
    phase_base = 'phase1 phase2 phase3'
    h          = 'h1     h2     h3'
  [../]

  [./global_strain]
    type = ComputeSmallStrain
    displacements = 'disp_x disp_y'
  [../]
[]

[Kernels]
  [./TensorMechanics]
    displacements = 'disp_x disp_y'
  [../]

  #Kernels for diffusion equation
  [./diff_time]
    type = TimeDerivative
    variable = c
  [../]
  [./diff_c1]
    type = MatDiffusion
    variable = c
    diffusivity = Dh1
    v = c1
  [../]
  [./diff_c2]
    type = MatDiffusion
    variable = c
    diffusivity = Dh2
    v = c2
  [../]
  [./diff_c3]
    type = MatDiffusion
    variable = c
    diffusivity = Dh3
    v = c3
  [../]

  # Kernels for Allen-Cahn equation for eta1
  [./deta1dt]
    type = TimeDerivative
    variable = eta1
  [../]
  [./ACBulkF1]
    type = KKSMultiACBulkF
    variable  = eta1
    Fj_names  = 'F1 F2 F3'
    hj_names  = 'h1 h2 h3'
    gi_name   = g1
    eta_i     = eta1
    wi        = 0.01
    args      = 'c1 c2 c3 eta2 eta3'
  [../]
  [./ACBulkC1]
    type = KKSMultiACBulkC
    variable  = eta1
    Fj_names  = 'F1 F2 F3'
    hj_names  = 'h1 h2 h3'
    cj_names  = 'c1 c2 c3'
    eta_i     = eta1
    args      = 'eta2 eta3'
  [../]
  [./ACInterface1]
    type = ACInterface
    variable = eta1
    kappa_name = kappa
  [../]

  # Kernels for Allen-Cahn equation for eta2
  [./deta2dt]
    type = TimeDerivative
    variable = eta2
  [../]
  [./ACBulkF2]
    type = KKSMultiACBulkF
    variable  = eta2
    Fj_names  = 'F1 F2 F3'
    hj_names  = 'h1 h2 h3'
    gi_name   = g2
    eta_i     = eta2
    wi        = 0.01
    args      = 'c1 c2 c3 eta1 eta3'
  [../]
  [./ACBulkC2]
    type = KKSMultiACBulkC
    variable  = eta2
    Fj_names  = 'F1 F2 F3'
    hj_names  = 'h1 h2 h3'
    cj_names  = 'c1 c2 c3'
    eta_i     = eta2
    args      = 'eta1 eta3'
  [../]
  [./ACInterface2]
    type = ACInterface
    variable = eta2
    kappa_name = kappa
  [../]

  # Kernels for constraint equation eta1 + eta2 + eta3 = 1
  # eta3 is the nonlinear variable for the constraint equation
  [./eta3reaction]
    type = MatReaction
    variable = eta3
    mob_name = 1
  [../]
  [./eta1reaction]
    type = MatReaction_abscouple
    variable = eta3
    v = eta1
    mob_name = 1
  [../]
  [./eta2reaction]
    type = MatReaction_abscouple
    variable = eta3
    v = eta2
    mob_name = 1
  [../]
  [./one]
    type = BodyForce
    variable = eta3
    value = -1.0
  [../]


  # Phase concentration constraints
  [./chempot12]
    type = KKSPhaseChemicalPotential
    variable = c1
    cb       = c2
    fa_name  = F1
    fb_name  = F2
  [../]
  [./chempot23]
    type = KKSPhaseChemicalPotential
    variable = c2
    cb       = c3
    fa_name  = F2
    fb_name  = F3
  [../]
  [./phaseconcentration]
    type = KKSMultiPhaseConcentration
    variable = c3
    cj = 'c1 c2 c3'
    hj_names = 'h1 h2 h3'
    etas = 'eta1 eta2 eta3'
    c = c
  [../]
[]

node.title: Navier-Stokes Module Maturity for sCO2 Application
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 Q&A Navier Stokes is the most appropriate category for my question
 I have consulted the posting Guidelines on the Discussions front page
 I have searched the Discussions forum and my question has not been asked before
 I have searched the MOOSE website and the documentation does not answer my question
 I have formatted my post following the posting guidelines (avoid screenshots if possible, triple back quotes before/after pasted text, etc)

Question
Hello All!
I am a newer user to MOOSE, and I am looking to model heat tranasfer through a radioisotope-heated core. For this system, supercritical carbon dioxide (sCO2) was selected as the working fluid. Previously, I had been looking into using established CFD solvers like OpenFOAM or NekRS to solve for the fluid flow, outlet temperature, pressure drop, and surface temperature. Before jumping into these other codes, I wanted to see whether MOOSE's Navier-Stokes module could handle a case like this. I will include more technical specs in the Additional information section below. The biggest issues I foresee are turbulence and compressibility. To be clear: I am not inquiring as to MOOSE's capabilities of modeling radiation, only on the thermal hydraulics.
TLDR: Can the Navier-Stokes module accurately simulate sCO2 to medium fidelity (or higher) for steady-state operation?
Thank you very much in advance!
Additional information
Mesh size and type:
Reynolds number: ~20,000
Discretization (finite element CG/DG, finite volume, etc): Finite Volume is preferred based on information from MOOSE's documentation
Models (turbulence, porous media, etc): Turbulent
Solver method (fully coupled, segregated, multiapps, etc): Unknown
Base input you started from: N/A
Operating Pressure: 15 MPa
Inlet Temperature: 320 K
Outlet Temperature (approximate): 600 K

hello
As long as you are not modeling a de-pressurization accident, you should be able to use the weakly compressible formulation to just model the coolant behavior.
The new linear finite volume solver should be able to handle several million dofs. How big is the system? and how many elements do you plan to use to mesh it?
For heat transfer, you ll be able to use correlations to compute the heat flux. Support for conjugate heat transfer will come later this year
Note that we have fluid properties for CO2 in the carbon_dioxide optional submodule of the fluid properties module of MOOSE. I have not tested them in the supercritical regime.
Guillaume

At the given operating temperatures and pressures and assuming negligible pressure drop (this is reasonable, as the fluid velocity is quite small), we get an inlet fluid density of 726.83 kg/m3 and an outlet fluid density of 135.43 kg/m3. This makes the ratio of outlet/inlet density as 18.63%. This seems like it would be too compressible for a weakly-compressible solver. What do you think?
Values taken from NIST: https://webbook.nist.gov/chemistry/fluid/
LP

Thanks for the extra info
@licharlot @joshuahansel @lingzou or @grmnptr what do you think on the applicability of a weakly compressible model here?

Sorry, I don't have a good idea on the transition point of when a weakly compressible model becomes acceptable, and I also don't know whether our CO2 properties handle supercritical CO2. I would guess we only have properties in the two-phase regime. We have CarbonDioxide(Liquid|Vapor|TwoPhase)FluidProperties, so I don't know where supercritical would fit in those.

Based on this documentation, it appears that MOOSE fluid properties can handle through supercritical. The equation of state given by Span and Wagner (which is what your code is based on) has a very wide range of validity.
If CFD analysis is not yet possible in MOOSE for what I need (which seems likely), would a coarser solver, say from the Thermal Hydraulics module, be able to just give surface and outlet temperatures (and maybe pressure drop)?

Ah ok thanks, I see this CO2FluidProperties now. That one is actually documented a little! I was referring to the ones in the modules/fluid_properties/contrib/carbon_dioxide module, which are not documented (and those might be applicable too, just don't know where the supercritical regime goes).
THM can be used if your flow is 1D, but we do not have a turbulence model for its flow model though. We would just need to ensure that your fluid properties class has all the necessary interfaces, but the class could be extended with the necessary interfaces if it doesn't already have them.
Also note that there is a fully compressible NS solver, but as I understand it, it's just not actively developed (focus is mainly on weakly compressible formulation). Also I think it may not have turbulence support. @GiudGiud @grmnptr can you comment?
I think would suggest just going for it with NS and doing a small sample problem in the supercritical regime, and then try out different formulations.

node.title: Equation with "if statements"
node.bodyText: Hi all, I am writing an equation (expression) that comprises "if statements" in my model as shown in the attached file. I just want to know if the equation is written correctly. if not I need correction on how best to write it in MOOSE. Thanks!

hello
no it's not. I dont know if && works so I d do this:
expression = 'if (t > 0, if(t<to, L0 * (1 + accslip / 0.0111), if (t<to + tf, L0 * (1 + accslip / 0.0111) * exp(-k * (t - to)), 0)), 0)'
regardless of if && works, you need to keep this if (a, b, c) structure, even when nesting ifs: if (a1, if(a2, b, d), c)

Thank you for your response
But the first  part  of second inequality condition "to < t" was not accounted for. Is it Ok to ignore it? Also some of the inequality conditions has something like "less than or equal to"

it is
 if(t<to, // this part only if t < to L0 * (1 + accslip / 0.0111), // this part only if t > to if (t<to + tf,

This the first part. there is less than and equality sign, ie t<=to

There is also less than and equality sign in the second part too ie t<=to + tf
could you please take a look
you can change < to <= in what I wrote

Yes, according to you, this is what I will have
expression = 'if (t > 0, if(t<=to, L0 * (1 + accslip / 0.001), if (t<=to + tf, L0 * (1 + accslip / 0.001) * exp(-k * (t - to)), 0)), 0)'
but my concern is that this part of inequality "to<t" in "to<t<=to + tf" is missing in the expression

It’s not missing.
if you don’t trust what I wrote please go to the ParsedFunction documentation then follow the link to the fparser documentation
Alright. Thanks a lot for your feedbacks, really appreciative

Good evening
So I got the following syntax error for the expression.
expression = 'if (t > 0, if(t <= to, L0 * (1 + accslip / 0.001), if (t<=to + tf, L0 * (1 + accslip / 0.001) * exp(-k * (t - to)), 0)), 0)'. I also remove the equality sign but i got same error. Please could help see if something is missing
can you paste the rest of the input? this does not look like an error on this line, but on two lines in the input
Please is there a way I can send the input script to you privately since the project is confidential to my research lab.?
sure. guillaume.giudicelli@inl.gov

Good day. I am modelling a new task where I am to apply symmetric boundary condition. Please see the figure attached. The domain is 7.2mm by 3.6mm. An initial semi elliptical pit is initiated at the center. The symmetrical boundary condition is applied at the x=3.6mm. How do I implement this symmetric BC? Thanks

symmetry boils down to 0 flux for many equations, and 0 flux is usually the default for most equations (so no BCs would be needed)
Does it do this for your equation?

We are not using any equation, just prescribing bc along the edges using DirichletBC as applied at the left boundary as shown. My concern is applying some kind of DirichletBC at center of the domain to make it symmetrical.

is applying some kind of DirichletBC at center of the domain to make it symmetrical.

a dirichletBC would not preclude symmetry but usually not necessary since the definition is 0 flux / 0 derivative (depending on the equation)

Ok thanks.
But how do I apply symmetrical BC in a domain in general?

node.title: Geoscience improvements: please vote!
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 Q&A General is the most appropriate section for my question
 I have consulted the posting Guidelines on the Discussions front page
 I have searched the Discussions forum and my question has not been asked before
 I have searched the MOOSE website and the documentation does not answer my question
 I have formatted my post following the posting guidelines (screenshots as a last resort, triple back quotes around pasted text)

Question
This week, at the MOOSE International Workshop a bunch of geoscientists met face-to-face and virtually to discuss improvements to the geoscience capability of MOOSE. Below, I've tried to list all the improvements mentioned. If you want to add something, please do!
Please vote on your favourites. Give yourself a small handful of "thumbs up" and vote on which improvements you like. This will allow developers to optimally plan.
MISCELLANEOUS "QUICK-FIX" IMPROVEMENTS

Include thermoviscous (possibly multiphase) flow with solidification
For instance, in volcanoes
Allow gravity to vary spatially and temporally in PorousFlow

Ability to do 3-phase (liquid-gas-solid) modelling
@cpgr : do we have this already?
Ability to do black-oil/compositional modelling.  Eg mixing of 2 gases and 1 liquid.  Compositional module would be even better for handling complex fluid interactions
Allow convergence criteria to change during a run

Pre-configure fluid-property packages
Having pre-set packages for common subsurface applications (e.g., hydrogen or methane properties) would speed up scripting and reduce setup time.

Improve steam/liquid convergence
This is difficult numerically, even when using non-(P,T) variables or variable switching, and we could possibly copy off other codes
Improve convergence for NCG

Improve numerical performance (MOOSE is slower than MODFLOW, PFLOTRAN)
This can be:

reduce un-needed computations (things in MOOSE framework that needn't be evaluated) especially for simple problems
improve stability
reduce number of nonlinear iterations (@WilkAndy feels this is difficult to improve unless stability is improved)
Dedicated TH-dependent diffusion coefficients such as De Vries
COMMUNITY

Make PorousFlow more attractive to new users

Perhaps create a GUI for model construction
More users would therefore help with code reviews
More examples and tutorials would be useful

particularly ones including solid mechanics (eg damage)
guidelines for constitutive models
guidelines regarding convergence problems, convergence criteria, convergence tolerances, variable scaling
Create a "geoscience virtual test bed", which would help with fully-functional examples
Publish comparisons with other codes

Encourage contributions
Instead of just creating our own MOOSE-Apps, can we contribute to PorousFlow (etc)?
Barriers:

worries that no other MOOSE users are actually interested in my contributions
SQA requirements
need more code reviewers, because framework people don't have expertise
difficult to create useful tests that have small runtimes and meshes
Incentives:
publication
MOOSE framework developers keep stuff up-to-date

Here is a comment from JoseB:
I've been thinking about how to ensure PorousFlow remains a lasting 
project rather than one that relies on the coding skills of just a few 
people. If we want to see it grow over time, I believe the number of 
contributors has to increase. The user base is key, as there's a clear 
correlation between the number of users, the ability to solve questions 
in the MOOSE discussion forum, and the overall development of the code.

ModFlow is, in my opinion, the perfect example of the direction 
PorousFlow should take. Without a GUI, ModFlow is quite difficult to 
master and prone to errors. However, with the addition of Python APIs 
and user-friendly interfaces, it became the go-to code for 
hydrogeologists. I think we can follow a similar path for 
PorousFlow—facilitating adoption through a well-designed GUI. User 
experience is crucial here.

Additionally, from my experience lecturing across Europe, I’ve noticed 
that young students are hesitant to learn a new code unless it offers a 
clear career advantage. Positioning PorousFlow as an easy-to-learn tool 
could help attract more users.

Of course, this involves significant development, but perhaps a hybrid 
business model—similar to what Kitware does—could support this effort. 
Providing high-quality open-source software while also offering 
consulting and custom development services might be a sustainable way 
forward.```
GENERAL MOOSE IMPROVEMENTS
Ease the meshing of complex geometries
DEM functionality in MOOSE
Include specialised elements in MOOSE, such as tri6, edge3, embeddedbeam, geogrid, connector (shell-shell, shell-beam)
Ability to include "stages" in input file for complicated time-dependent engineering simulations.  Eg, https://github.com/jmeier/moose-codeplugin-stages
Ability to plugin parts of MooseApps to other MooseApps.  Eg, https://github.com/jmeier/mooseapp-code-plugin

Parameterisation and varying parameters

Easy calibration.  Often, we have a few observations, and want to figure out the best (set of?) material properties like permeability.  Perhaps using adjoints or PEST?
Want ability to Monte-Carlo our parameters.  Also, ability to Monte-Carlo our geometry

Parameterisation and varying parameters
1. Easy calibration.  Often, we have a few observations, and want to figure out the best (set of?) material properties like permeability.  Perhaps using adjoints or PEST?

2. Want ability to Monte-Carlo our parameters.  Also, ability to Monte-Carlo our geometry


Does @lynnmunday agree that (1) can be done using Optimization, and (2) can be done using StochasticTools?

WELLBORE FUNCTIONALITY
Improve handling of wellbores
Would like (multiphase) flow (NS maybe THM) inside the wellbore
Would like to couple this (potentially through casing perforations) to PorousFlow in the reservoir
We have been doing this--will try to put an example together this spring

We have been doing this--will try to put an example together this spring

Sounds great, Robert! I am looking forward to your examples. Thanks
We plan to integrate our MOSKITO  work into MOOSE. The detailed plan is being prepared.

GEOCHEMISTRY ENHANCEMENTS

transport of Geochem + PorousFlow to be better explained and be simplified
need to improve accuracy for very saline groundwaters
need to improve accuracy for high tempnerature
terminology needs to be better explained for non-experts
improve error messaging during the solve
IMPROVED SOLID MECHANICS

Improve large deformations

This often occurs in soil mechanics and inside/around fractures.  Currently get poor convergence and it's difficult to understand

Tidy and enhance solid-mechanics plasticity + damage
There are two facets here:

It's difficult to understand which version of plasticity should be used: it seems a consolidation would be useful to users
Current plasticity models are sometimes too inflexible to use effectively, Eg, we'd like to have spatially-dependent plastic parameters

Add more constitutive, plasticity + damage models

hardening soil
construction concrete
Ability to do structural mechanics

FRACTURES
The meeting on March 11 decided to focus on this, in particular the non-growing fracture case.  Here are some notes:

fractures will typically have O(1mm) aperture, be planar with O(10m) extent, sitting in O(1km) model
fractures will typically form a network with complicated geometry
we don't really care whether fractures are meshed as 2D elements, 3D elements, or not even meshed at all, but we would like the following functionality:
Fluid and heat flow through the fractures
Fluid flow in the bulk
Ability to turn on/off fluid/heat transfer between bulk and fracture (which may be non-trivial since fluid/heat that "lives at" nodes that are shared by fracture and bulk may not be properly attributed to fracture and bulk)
Geochemistry in fracture and bulk
Solid mechanics in fracture and bulk.  So, external stresses should be able to open/close (but not over-close!) and shear fractures
Fluid and heat in fracture and bulk can change fracture aperture (which will change fracture permeability) so need to take into consideration of stresses in bulk
Geochemistry in fracture can change fracture aperture, viz dissolution/precipitation

Fracture initiation and propagation (eg in hydrofracturing or electrical fracking) may then be possible

node.title: Execute in parallel for self-implemented kernel
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 Q&A General is the most appropriate section for my question
 I have consulted the posting Guidelines on the Discussions front page
 I have searched the Discussions forum and my question has not been asked before
 I have searched the MOOSE website and the documentation does not answer my question
 I have formatted my post following the posting guidelines (screenshots as a last resort, triple back quotes around pasted text)

Question
Hi MOOSE community,
I am wondering if there is any further references on how to execute in parallel for a user-implemented kernel?
Many thanks!

Hello
User created kernels will run fine in parallel in the vast majority of cases. kernels are implementing a term in a element-quadrature point loop, so those are naturally distributed across all parallel processes.
Are you hitting an issue?

Thanks for following up and sorry for the late reply.
I now think the problem is with the parallel execution itself, regardless of which kernel.

this happens when the mpi distribution you are using for execution is not the same as the one you used for compilation
you can use which mpicc and which mpiexec to check

Edit: both projects have the path to the mpi from the moose environment. I did not conda activate moose for the first one.
Thanks so much for the reply! One interesting thing is that I got different locations from different moose projects.
In one of my projects,
$ which mpiexec
/usr/bin/mpiexec

$ which mpicc
/usr/bin/mpicc

while in the other,
$ which mpiexec
/home/hemiao/miniforge/envs/moose/bin/mpiexec

$ which mpicc
/home/hemiao/miniforge/envs/moose/bin/mpicc

The second one below gives the correct number of processors.
Parallelism:
  Num Processors:          4
  Num Threads:             1

Is there a way to change the path in the first project?
The PATH environment variable should be modified to make sure the MPI you want to use gets discovered first

node.title: Meshing and Connecting Parts from .stl Files
node.bodyText:
Hello,
I have created a CAD model the includes different materials and structures. As in, this CAD model has multiple bodies in the file, and each body (and its mesh) can be easily exported as a .stl file (though there are many options for this). Since each body will have different materials and perhaps different physics kernels assigned to it, I would like to see about importing each separately to its own Mesh object in MOOSE.
My questions are thus:

Would this method be recommended to ensure that the input file is kept clean and organized?
Since .stl files only contain the mesh, not the boundary names, is there a streamlined/easy way to import these meshes and assign boundary names for future boundary condition assignments?
Instead of meshing separately, say using Gmsh or another utility, could MOOSE simply import the CAD file (in whatever format is needed) and mesh within MOOSE, again assigning boundary names? If so, are there any controls over the type of mesh (tetrahedrals vs hexahedrals)?

Thank you very much in advance!!!
P.S. For reference I have included an image of the CAD model, which was created with FreeCAD. Though relatively simple, I am hoping to grow the model and design over time.

Hi

Would this method be recommended to ensure that the input file is kept clean and organized?

likely not. Importing the mesh in one FileMeshGenerator will make your Mesh block fairly tidy.
However, each part should be its own subdomain so you can assign equations and materials on a per-subdomain basis.
Importing each part separately would also not easily get the mesh connectivity you need for most physics. There are ways around non-conformal meshes for some physics but not all.

Since .stl files only contain the mesh, not the boundary names, is there a streamlined/easy way to import these meshes and assign boundary names for future boundary condition assignments?

stl files contain the CAD, not really the mesh. In your meshing tool, I think FreeCAD, you assign the boundary names then export it to a mesh format. This export should conserve the boundary names you assigned, but it's worth checking in Paraview if it did.

Instead of meshing separately, say using Gmsh or another utility, could MOOSE simply import the CAD file (in whatever format is needed) and mesh within MOOSE, again assigning boundary names? If so, are there any controls over the type of mesh (tetrahedrals vs hexahedrals)?

not at the moment. Support for meshing clean STL files is not very far away though, and we would be able to create a tet mesh there.
Feel free to create a feature request on the libmesh repo.
Guillaume

Thank you!
Would you know of any example input files in MOOSE repo that I could look at for reference, specifically for assigning different materials and kernels to different subdomains?
see test/tests/./materials/active_material_props/check_active_props.i

node.title: Variational inequality solver and non-linear elements
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 Q&A General is the most appropriate section for my question
 I have consulted the posting Guidelines on the Discussions front page
 I have searched the Discussions forum and my question has not been asked before
 I have searched the MOOSE website and the documentation does not answer my question
 I have formatted my post following the posting guidelines (screenshots as a last resort, triple back quotes around pasted text)

Question
Hi all,
There appears to be an issue with petsc's inequality solver and non-linear elements: The vinewtonrsls petsc method seems to be incorrectly enforcing constraints.
For example, the following input file has a ADTimeDerivative and ADBodyForce kernel. The body force kernel is trying to drive the variable below zero, however, there is a constraint to not let the variable go below zero.
Attached are the mesh files for the tet10's and tet4's
box_tet.zip
[Mesh]
    [fmg]
        type = FileMeshGenerator
        file = 'box_tet10.msh'
    []
[]

[Variables]
    [d]
        order = SECOND
    []
[]

[AuxVariables]
    [bounds_dummy]
        order = SECOND
    []
[]

[Bounds]
    [irreversibility]
        type = VariableOldValueBounds
        variable = bounds_dummy
        bounded_variable = d
        bound_type = lower
    []
[]

[Kernels]
    [diff]
        type = ADTimeDerivative
        variable = d
    []
    [body]
        type = ADBodyForce
        variable = d
        value = -0.1
    []
[]

[Executioner]
    type = Transient
    dt = 1
    end_time = 2
    solve_type = 'NEWTON'

    petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -snes_type -snes_vi_monitor'
    petsc_options_value = 'lu vinewtonrsls true'
    nl_abs_tol = 1e-08
    nl_rel_tol = 1e-06


     [Quadrature]
         order = FOURTH
     []
[]
[Outputs]
    exodus = true
[]

When using linear elements, this is enforced correctly (d=0 on all nodes), however, when using non-linear tet10's, the following field is generated:

I don't have any leads for this. I checked the bounds vector being generated by BoundsBase.C and it seems correct.
Any insight would be appreciated!

hi
thanks for reporting. I ll take a look

node.title: How to ensure the displaced mesh is used
node.bodyText:
Hello MOOSE Community,
I'm developing a custom material class that inherits from ADMaterial. The coordinates of the current quadrature point will be used as a condition to assign a specific value to some created variables. What I want to know is whether the coordinates of _q_point[_qp](0), _q_point[_qp](1) and _q_point[_qp](2) return the displaced mesh or the undisplaced mesh. Since I need the coordinates of the quadrature point under the displaced mesh, what should I do to ensure that the displaced mesh is always used?

For many objects, all you need to do is setting use_displaced_mesh = true
Is that an option for your case?

The intended behavior is that when you set this parameter to true, the _mesh attribute in the back will refer to the displaced mesh. And the _problem or _fe_problem would refer to the displaced problem.
Similarly q_point and other mesh quantities would come from the displaced configuration
If you are not observing that, I'll look into it to make sure it is as expected.

For many objects, all you need to do is setting use_displaced_mesh = true

I haven't done that yet.

The intended behavior is that when you set this parameter to true, the _mesh attribute in the back will refer to the displaced mesh. And the _problem or _fe_problem would refer to the displaced problem.

Thank you for your kind explanation. But do we have a parameter that can 'globally' set all objects to use the displaced mesh, as there are usually a number of objects used in an input file? Another question is since all the objects I have developed myself have no declared parameter called use_displaced_mesh and I don't know how to pass it to the parent class either. Sorry, I am not good at C++. In this case, can I just set use_displaced_mesh = true on each object to get all the physics in the simulation to use the displaced mesh? Or what else should I do?
In my simulation, the problem is set to FEProblem. Below are the results I saw from my simulation with use_displaced_mesh = true set for the mechanics only, but not for the rest of the physics. Here the I_aux represents the variation of the light intensity along the y-axis direction. As you can see in the zoomed image, the I_aux should be non-zero for nodes on the right-hand side of the red line. However, when I checked in the paraview, the values for the highlight element are unexpected. I_aux_node_1 = I_aux_node_4 = 0.0 whereas they should be around 10 or so.
Overall view of the part

Zoom in on the top left corner

You can set use_displaced_mesh = true in the GlobalParams block to have it be applied to all objects
The derived classes you created do not use that parameter directly, but it is used by the parent classes to set the various attributes you use in the derived classes. So it still works as expected, unless you retrieved mesh items directly, not leveraging the base class

You can set use_displaced_mesh = true in the GlobalParams block to have it be applied to all objects

Thank you very much. I will test it this afternoon. I don't think the developed classes retrieve the mesh items directly as I didn't include any libmesh header files except the one dealing with moving the boundary between domains.

I developed a class "PrintQuadraturePointCoordinates" to output the _q_point[_qp](0) and _q_point[_qp](1) of the upper right corner element (ID=49) within a large deformation simulation. The use_displaced_mesh = true is defined as a global parameter. Results show the _q_point[_qp](0) and _q_point[_qp](1) return the undeformed quadrature point coordinates.
The geometry is 2 x 1 with a mesh size of 10 x 5, so the coordinates of the undeformed mesh can be easily calculated:
qp = 0, x = 2 - 0.2/2 - 0.2/2/sqrt(3) =  1.842264973, y = 1 - 0.2/2 - 0.2/2/sqrt(3) = 0.842264973
qp = 1, x = 2 - 0.2/2 + 0.2/2/sqrt(3) =  1.957735027, y = 1 - 0.2/2 + 0.2/2/sqrt(3) = 0.957735027

These results  are the same as the output from the "PrintQuadraturePointCoordinates" class. I append the output at the end.
But if I want to use the coordinates of the deformed mesh, what should I do? Do you have any suggestions?
Header file
#pragma once

#include "ADMaterial.h"

class PrintQuadraturePointCoordinates : public ADMaterial
{
public:
  static InputParameters validParams();
  PrintQuadraturePointCoordinates(const InputParameters & parameters);

  virtual void computeQpProperties() override;        
};

Source file
#include "PrintQuadraturePointCoordinates.h"

registerMooseObject("MechanicsApp", PrintQuadraturePointCoordinates);

InputParameters
PrintQuadraturePointCoordinates::validParams()
{
  InputParameters params = ADMaterial::validParams();
  params.addClassDescription("Displaced mesh test");

  return params;
}

PrintQuadraturePointCoordinates::PrintQuadraturePointCoordinates(const InputParameters & parameters)
  : ADMaterial(parameters)
{
}

void PrintQuadraturePointCoordinates::computeQpProperties()
{
  Real x = _q_point[_qp](0);
  Real y = _q_point[_qp](1);

  const unsigned int elem_id = _current_elem->id();

  if (elem_id == 49){
    std::cout << "Element ID = " << elem_id 
            << ", qp = " << _qp 
            << ", x = " << x 
            << ", y = " << y 
            << std::endl;
  }
}

Input file

  dim = 2
  xmin = 0
  ymin = 0

  nx = 10
  ny = 5
[]

[]

    component = 0
    variable = disp_x
  [../]

  [./fix_bottom_y]

  [../]

  [../]

[]

node.title: Scenarios for using the multiapp and transfer system
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 Q&A General is the most appropriate section for my question
 I have consulted the posting Guidelines on the Discussions front page
 I have searched the Discussions forum and my question has not been asked before
 I have searched the MOOSE website and the documentation does not answer my question
 I have formatted my post following the posting guidelines (screenshots as a last resort, triple back quotes around pasted text)

Question
Hello developers,
Currently I am using moose framework to access two external programs, and I want to complete the moose framework through the "tight" coupling of the two programs, through the official website I learned that multi-app and transfer is mainly used in some loosely coupled or decoupled scenarios. So I am curious, for the tightly coupled scenario of two external programs, can I continue to use the multi-app and transfer system, for example, when I iterate in picard, since I am not sure how many times I iterate before convergence, at this time I should be in the input card how to set up the execution_time of the transfer, or should I use another function module to accomplish my current picard iteration I'm looking forward to your answer.
Very much looking forward to your answers.

hello

through the official website I learned that multi-app and transfer is mainly used in some loosely coupled or decoupled scenarios

multiapps can do tight coupling too. You just need to set fixed point iteration parameters to the executioner. Notably change the max number of fixed point iterations.

since I am not sure how many times I iterate before convergence, at this time I should be in the input card how to set up the execution_time of the transfer

there are a variety of convergence criteria available, notably using a postprocessor value which is a very flexible option
